message: Wishing you and your family a safe, happy and prosperous 2017. Happy New Years!
I voted against the proposed changes to the House's Office of Congressional Ethics last night and I was pleased to see them removed from the House Rules package that will be adopted later today.
Some high-quality programming on World War I going on this month at the Haverford Township Free Library, made possible by a grant from the National Endowment for the Humanities.

Thank you to all who contacted me regarding proposed changes to the Office of Congressional Ethics. I opposed these changes when they were brought up for a vote among members of the House Republican Conference on Monday. And I’m pleased to report that these changes ultimately were not included in the rules package that Congress passed yesterday.   I’ve also opposed efforts in the past to eliminate or reduce funding for the Office of Congressional Ethics.  Pennsylvania families deserve to know that their elected officials are serving them honorably and ethically. As a prosecutor, I worked hard to protect the public trust by cracking down on corruption in politics.   Today, I have the privilege of serving on the House Ethics Committee, where I’m working to hold my fellow lawmakers to rigorous standards and ensure Members of Congress and staff that commit wrongdoing are held accountable.  Thank you again for contacting me on this issue.

Overwhelming bipartisan vote tonight against the anti-Israel U.N. Security Council resolution passed late last month. The U.N.'s move wasn't just anti-Israel -- it made the prospect of peace in the region less obtainable. Tonight's vote shows that despite President Obama's eleventh hour abandonment, Congress' support for the U.S.-Israel alliance is as strong as ever.
Honoring all the men and women of law enforcement this #LawEnforcementAppreciationDay

Inauguration Ticket Update: Our lottery drawing is complete and my staff is in the process of notifying ticket recipients. Demand for tickets was tremendous and unfortunately far outpaced the supply. We’ll be picking up the tickets later today, and instructions for distribution next week will follow.

In honor of #LawEnforcementAppreciationDay I'm displaying these blue lights in my office window to show solidarity with the men and women of law enforcement who put their lives on the line to protect our communities.
Great news for jobs in our region.

Thank you to all who applied to receive tickets to next week’s Presidential Inauguration. Each Congressional office received a limited number of tickets for the Swearing-In Ceremony, and due to overwhelming demand a lottery system was instituted to fairly allocate those tickets. The lottery process is now complete and each ticket recipient has been contacted directly by my staff. No more tickets will be available through our office.    Additional information regarding the Inaugural events and committees can be found at http://www.inaugural.senate.gov/. Thank you again for your interest in being a part of the 58th Presidential Inauguration on Friday, January 20, 2017.

Today is National Human Trafficking Awareness Day -- take a moment to learn more about trafficking in our own region, learn to spot the signs of trafficking and how victims can get help by visiting the National Human Trafficking Hotline's website.
One of the great pleasures of this job: calling students last night to inform them that they'll be receiving one of my primary nominations to our nation's uniformed service academies.

Saddened to hear of John's passing. His advocacy opened my eyes to some of the challenges facing many navy veterans of the Vietnam War and led me to co-sponsor the Blue Water Navy Vietnam Veterans Act.
"Darkness cannot drive out darkness, only light can do that. Hate cannot drive out hate; only love can do that." - Martin Luther King Jr.
Greatful for the opportunity to spend Martin Luther King Day honoring MLK's legacy at the 16th Annual Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. CommUNITY Breakfast in Kennett Square.
Had the chance to talk to farmers about some of the issues facing the agriculture industry at the Honey Brook Township Farmer's breakfast this morning.

Met with seniors today to discuss legislation I’m championing that makes Medicare work better for seniors. The bill gives seniors access to educational resources to help them better understand their Medicare eligibility and avoid penalties for late enrollment. I was joined by a few of my constituents who have personally faced the complexity of the maze of Medicare enrollment deadlines and regulations.

Great to be on hand this evening as State Farm announced a grant of nearly $100,000 in support of a state of the art aquaponics lab at Interboro High School. It's a great example of the ways we can better educate kids for the jobs of the modern economy by partnering the private sector with our schools.

Joined Congressman Ryan Costello this morning at the John Heinz National Wildlife Refuge At Tinicum to celebrate the creation of the Delaware River Basin Conservation Act, which will help us protect and preserve the Delaware River Watershed. The bill was included in a larger water resources bill approved by Congress late last year.
Widespread power outages are affecting the entire region. Here are numbers you need to know to report an outage:  PECO: 1-800-841-4141 PPL: 1-800-342-5775  Met-Ed: 1-888-544-4877
My Springfield District Office is currently experiencing a power outage. If you need immediate assistance, please contact my Washington, DC office at (202) 225-2011.
Looking forward to welcoming my Republican colleagues to our region later this week.
Shared a few of the many stories from Pennsylvania families struggling under Obamacare at a hearing of the Committee on Ways and Means' Oversight Subcommittee this afternoon.
Joined my friend Congressman Dwight Evans on Good Day Philadelphia this morning to talk about this week's Republican Policy Conference in Philadelphia.
Thank you to all the many Pennsylvania families who made the trip to Washington for today's March for Life -- and thank you to the members of my team on hand on Capitol Hill to greet them.
Paying tribute to the memory of the victims of the Holocaust this Holocaust Remembrance Day.

My first and foremost responsibility as a member of Congress is the security of the United States. As a former U.S. Attorney and member of the Homeland Security Committee, I know terror groups have long sought to both exploit gaps in our immigration screening and use refugee status as a cover to reach our shores and murder our citizens. It’s only responsible that we take immediate steps to protect our citizens and prevent terrorists from entering the U.S.   I do, however, have concerns with the way this order was drafted and implemented. It appears to have inadvertently harmed families already in transit to the U.S., immigrants who have already completed the rigorous green card screening process, and interpreters and others who have aided our forces overseas. I’m going to work with my colleagues to press for screening policies that are fair, responsible and effective in keeping Americans safe.

Had the honor of being on hand today as a portion of Lansdowne Avenue in Delaware County was dedicated as Officer Dennis McNamara Memorial Highway in honor of the Upper Darby Police Officer who lost his life in the line of duty 15 years ago today.

Paid tribute on the House floor a few moments ago to Officer Dennis McNamara of the Upper Darby Police Department, tragically shot and killed in the line of duty fifteen years ago yesterday. I joined Senator Tom McGarrigle and PA State Rep. Jamie Santora yesterday to dedicate a portion of Lansdowne Avenue as "Officer Dennis McNamara Highway".
Had the chance to say hello to some students from Chichester High School in Washington, D.C. today as part of the Close Up program.

Bradley Whitford of The West Wing stopped by today to talk about the importance of protecting our environment, preserving it for future generations of Americans and combating the effects of climate change.

Bill Dondero from my District Office was on hand today for the grand opening of the newly-renovated Building 69 at the Coatesville VA Medical Center. The new building centralizes physical & occupational therapy, prosthetics and other services in a single location -- making them easier for our vets to access.

For years, the Obama Administration bent over backwards to accommodate Iran in its quest to secure and protect its nuclear deal. Iran’s development of its ballistic missile program shows its belligerence and aggression continue unabated. These sanctions are a responsible, warranted consequence of Iran’s actions – and a clear signal to the Iranian regime that the days of endless American accommodation are over.
At a hearing of the Bipartisan Heroin Task Force this afternoon to hear from experts on the science and treatment of synthetic opioids.

Veterans and their family members are invited to a Veterans Town Hall to meet with and hear from leaders from the Department of Veterans Affairs tomorrow Wednesday, February 8th, at 2pm at the Crescenz VA Medical Center.

Thank you to the thousands of seniors who tuned into our telephone town hall meeting this morning -- our second in less than a week. I also spent some time today responding directly to some of the letters and e-mails our office has received over the course of the last several weeks. I always appreciate the benefit of people's views and I enjoy the chance to hear their stories and concerns.

Due to today's inclement weather, my Springfield District Office will be closed today, Thursday, February 9th. Should you be in need of assistance you can contact my Washington, D.C. office at (202) 225-2011.

This morning I had the privilege of honoring the 7th District’s Service Academy Nominees at Valley Forge Military Academy & College. I would like to thank our nomination board for all for their hard work and dedication in selecting this year’s nominees. I am very proud of this group of students and it is an honor to serve as their Representative in Congress.
It's an honor to nominate each of these fine young people for admission to our nation's uniformed service academies. Congratulations to all.

Vice President Pence was on Capitol Hill today -- I had the opportunity to speak with him share with him information about legislation I'm working on to make a college degree more affordable and more obtainable.

Our region's community colleges are so important in helping students access quality, affordable higher education. Pleased to welcome Delaware County Community College President Jerry Parker and members of the DCCC board to Washington this morning.

Staffers in my District Office do terrific work helping constituents cut through the federal bureaucracy and get the answers, services and benefits they need. But I was pleased to have the chance today to speak in support of legislation on the House floor this week that will cut red tape in casework and make their difficult jobs just a little bit easier.
Had the chance to sit down with constituents from Moms Clean Air Force this morning to talk about the importance of protecting our environment and ensuring clean air.

Had a chance to meet the employees, take some questions and tour the impressive facilities at New Hudson Facades, which manufactures curtain wall and building envelopes for the construction industry in Linwood, Delaware County.
Had the chance to join Wawa and Big Brothers Big Sisters Independence Region on Wednesday for their "Beyond School Walls" event celebrating their one-on-one mentoring program benefiting local kids.

Hundreds of thousands of dollars are owed to our school districts by tax delinquent landlords receiving federal Section 8 Housing funds. Here's a way we're trying to get those districts the dollars they're owed -- and lower property tax burdens for homeowners.
Had the opportunity to stop by a fundraising event over the weekend for Homes for Heroes, which benefits homeless veterans .

Testifying a few moments ago to urge my colleagues on the House Appropriations Committee to include robust funding for specialized veterans' treatment courts that help vets coping with PTSD, addiction and other conditions get the care they need.
I spoke this morning with members of the House Committee on Appropriations - Republicans to urge funding for veterans' treatment courts -- so important to helping so many vets in our area.

I think there was a lot to like in the President's address last night. I was pleased to hear him discuss the need to put Americans back to work and reform our broken tax code. I was pleased to hear him reiterate his commitment to repealing Obamacare and making health care more affordable and more accessible for middle class patients. And I was encouraged by the President's tone and call for unity among both Republicans and Democrats. I'm hopeful his speech will be a starting point for real bipartisan cooperation on the challenges facing our nation today.
With my guest for last night's address by the President to a Joint Session of Congress: Delco's State Rep. and PA National Guardsman Nick Miccarelli.

The American people must be able to have confidence in the integrity of any inquiry into Russian activities and Attorney General Sessions’ involvement would undermine this confidence. The Attorney General’s testimony during his confirmation has clearly been called into question by news reports indicating he met with the Russian Ambassador prior to the election. Attorney General Sessions should recuse himself and clarify the testimony he gave the Senate prior to his confirmation.

Paid tribute this afternoon to the great work done by Robert and Megan Trinkley and the many friends and supporters of Mission First Housing's Homes for Heroes, which raises tens of thousands of dollars each year to help provide our veterans with safe, affordable housing.

Enjoyed the opportunity to speak with small and medium-sized business leaders in Berks County this afternoon as part of the Greater Reading Chamber of Commerce & Industry's Congressional Conversation series. Among the topics discussed: repealing and replacing Obamacare and fixing our broken tax code.

Do you use the U.S. Department of Education's Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA) website? The Department is seeking input as it designs an updated site -- use this link to provide your feedback.
NA
A packed house this morning for our annual Academy Day information session with Congressman Ryan Costello. Always encouraging to see so many young people eager to serve their country.
With Philadelphia Rose of Tralee Brigid Gallagher of Havertown at the Philadelphia St. Patrick's Day Parade this morning.
NA
Due to the winter storm, my Springfield District Office is closed today, Tuesday, March 14th. Should you need immediate assistance, please contact my Washington, D.C. office at (202) 225-2011.
Power outages are affecting our entire region. Here are the phone numbers you need to know to report an outage: PECO: 1-800-841-4141 PPL: 1-800-342-5775  Met-Ed: 1-888-544-4877

For those interested in visiting Washington D.C. for Easter – the 139th White House Easter Egg Roll is set to take place on Monday, April 17, 2017, on the South Lawn of the White House.   White House Easter Egg Roll tickets are free to the public and can be requested through an online ticket lottery opening today, Wednesday, March 15, 2017, at 12:00 PM and closing on Saturday, March 18, 2017, at 12:00 PM. Entering the lottery is free of charge, and winners will be notified via email on Friday, March 31, 2017. Those interested in attending can enter the lottery by clicking on the link below.
Joined 16 of my GOP colleagues today to introduce a resolution urging action to address the risks and implications of climate change.

Budgets are about priorities, and the budget request submitted to Congress today reflects a different set of priorities than the ones I’ve set. There are some things to like in this budget. It includes $500 million in additional funding to combat the opioid crisis. It adds funding for veterans’ health care. It also includes good news for the workers at Boeing’s facility in Delaware County: it replaces a V-22 Osprey lost in combat in Yemen earlier this year.  But I also have some serious concerns. It reduces funding for the National Institutes of Health. It includes significant cuts to the Environmental Protection Agency, which may hamper its ability to protect our air and drinking water. And it cuts federal protection for national parks and federal lands by 75 percent, which could endanger conservation efforts in Pennsylvania at sites like Gettysburg National Military Park.  Ultimately, I expect Congress will take the White House’s request into consideration – but the Constitution gives Congress the power of the purse. As the budget process continues, I’ll keep on fighting to ensure we’re both making good use of taxpayer dollars and funding the services and programs important to Pennsylvania families.

I’ve long said we need to repeal Obamacare and replace it with real reforms that address the cost of care and make quality coverage more affordable.  The bill took important steps to dismantle Obamacare’s maze of taxes and mandates, and it also preserved protections for people with pre-existing conditions – a top priority of mine throughout this debate. But I also expressed serious concerns about just what this bill would have meant for Pennsylvania.   This legislation didn’t go far enough to bring down the cost of care or make essential coverage more affordable. Ultimately, this bill was not a satisfactory repeal of Obamacare, nor an adequate replacement.   But this issue isn’t going away. With more time and more feedback from members and their constituents, I hope we’ll be able to continue the repeal-and-replace process. It’s more important we get this done right than get it done fast.

Congratulations to Lisa Carney, a fourth grade teacher at Delaware County's St. Bernadette of Lourdes elementary school, on being recognized with the Federal Bar Association’s Excellence in Civics Education Award -- given to just 22 teachers nationwide this year.

Was on hand this morning to read to students at Devereux Advanced Behavioral Health Pennsylvania in West Chester for their 14th Annual Reading Week. I’m grateful to have an organization like Devereux serving children and young adults with intellectual and developmental disabilities in the 7th District.
Today my staff had a table set up at Ridley Health Awareness Day at Ridley High School. It was a great and informative event with more than 75 vendors in attendance.
Don't miss my op-ed in The Hill that talks about the need for the U.S. to be a global leader in securing our financial networks from cyber attack.
Watch now as my colleagues and I launch a bipartisan task force to end sexual violence.

Had the opportunity to speak with Ashley Murosky of Wayne, Delaware County on Wednesday to hear her incredible story -- she's coping with lung cancer and was on Capitol Hill Wednesday to fight for more funding for the National Institutes of Health. It's such an important issue that affects millions of American families.

There’s more that we can do at the federal level to prevent sexual violence and aid the victims and those who support them. This task force will build off the successful model of the Bipartisan Heroin Task Force – work collaboratively, across party lines, identify challenges and find areas of common ground in solving them.

Joined more than 200 of my colleagues -- Republican and Democrat -- today to urge a robust $36 billion in funding for the National Institutes of Health, which does tremendous work to find groundbreaking new cures and treatments for conditions that affect millions of Americans.
Watch Now: Congressman Meehan, survivors and advocates press for more funding for research and prevention of brain aneurysms in Wayne, Delaware County.

Earlier this week, we saw the Assad regime perpetrate a vicious chemical weapons attack that killed or wounded countless innocent civilians.   Last night's strikes were a decisive and proportional response that showed Assad his alliance with Russia does not give him blank check to commit war crimes. He cannot continue to conduct indiscriminate attacks against his own citizens with weapons of mass destruction.   We sent Assad’s regime and his Russian allies a message: no longer will their actions go without consequence. They will pay a price. Last night, they did. It’s a message I hope they heard loud and clear. There is simply no place for such atrocities.
Watch Now: In Media this afternoon to present a flag flown over the U.S. Capitol to Aminata Soumano, an African woman who just passed her citizenship test and will soon be an American Citizen.
Was on hand this morning at Saint Joseph's University Kinney Center to learn more about the great work they do to support children and adults with Autism.

This morning I attended a conference at the Field Center for Children’s Policy, Practice, and Research at the University of Pennsylvania to talk about the work I’m doing in Congress to prevent human trafficking here and abroad.

Some good news: Pennsylvania is set to receive $26.5 million through a federal grant to help combat the opioid crisis. The grant is authorized by landmark bipartisan opioid legislation passed by Congress last year. It will put more resources in the hands of those on the front lines of the fight against opioid addiction in Pennsylvania.  Pennsylvania is set to receive the fourth-largest federal grant awarded, following only California, Texas and Florida.  I'm pleased to see Pennsylvania receive such a significant share of funding -- but it's also a somber recognition of the fact that our communities have been hit particularly hard by this epidemic.

This morning, I met with Joshua Chu, a senior at Wissahickon High School, and presented him with the Bronze Congressional Award. The Congressional Award was established by Congress in 1979 to recognize achievement and service in young people. Joshua earned the award by achieving challenging goals in four areas: voluntary public service, personal development, physical fitness and expedition/exploration. Congratulations to Joshua for earning the Bronze Congressional Award!

My District Representative, Bill Dondero, has a table set up at Rep. Mark Gillen's Veterans Expo at the Barn at Flying Hills in Reading. Bill will be on hand at the expo until 2:00 pm.  Military veterans and their families are encouraged to stop by to learn more about the resources available to them.

On the proposed changes to the Obamacare repeal bill: I said in March that the legislation was neither a satisfactory repeal of Obamacare, nor an adequate replacement. It threatens to send premiums skyrocketing for people with pre-existing conditions. It will make coverage more expensive for older Americans as they near retirement. And it threatens essential healthcare benefits like doctor’s office visits, opioid addiction treatment and emergency room care.   The MacArthur amendment does not adequately address the concerns I had with the bill as it stood then, and I will oppose the legislation should it come to the House floor. I’m going to keep working to repeal and replace Obamacare with real reforms that make care more affordable and more accessible to Pennsylvania families.

CBS Philly tells the story of Sue Ingram Widemann, a victim of sexual assault in a massage establishment that had the bravery to come forward, tell her story -- and begin an effort to prevent similar assaults in the future.
Some important information from the VA about an ongoing scam that mimics the Veterans Choice Program's phone number.
Joined MSNBC's Craig Melvin this afternoon to talk about some of the issues of the day, health care and averting a government shutdown among them.
On hand this morning as Springfield Township, Delaware County honored it's finest in the township's 25th Annual Loyalty Day

Joined the Brandywine Conservancy yesterday for the ribbon-cutting and dedication of Founder's Grove and the Harvey Run Trail -- beautiful tracts of open space in Chadds Ford now available for residents from around the region to enjoy.
Joined CNN's Chris Cuomo to talk about a bipartisan deal to avert a government shutdown and other news of the day this morning.

Joined Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke -- a former House colleague of mine -- on Capitol Hill this morning to talk about the preservation of the Beaver Valley open space in Concord Township, Delaware County.

I’ve been a leader in the fight to repeal and replace Obamacare. I hear from constituents every day who face higher costs for less coverage. There’s no question Obamacare is unsustainable.But this legislation doesn’t keep the promises I made to my constituents when I said I would do it.  It threatens people with pre-existing conditions with skyrocketing costs. It threatens essential healthcare coverage like mental health and opioid addiction treatments. Monthly premiums for many, particularly older Americans nearing retirement, will rise. This bill doesn’t repeal or fix Obamacare – it simply shifts its failures from one group of Americans to another.  Even after major changes to the legislation, the House voted today without the benefit of a CBO score that will tell us how much it costs or what it may mean for coverage. It’s the product of the same broken process and last-minute deal-making that gave us Obamacare.  Now the bill goes to the Senate, where the bill will likely see significant revision. I hope that those changes address the concerns I have and that I’m able to support a final repeal-and-replace bill.

Dispose of your personal documents securely: join us on Saturday, May 13 for a FREE drive-thru shred event. We'll also have a secure prescription drug drop box that will allow you to dispose of medications, as well.

Grateful to PA State Rep. Jamie Santora and the folks from Clifton Heights for hosting such an important community forum on the opioid crisis rocking Pennsylvania last night. Combating this crisis will take commitment and cooperation at every level of government.
REMINDER: Free drive-thru shred event at my Springfield District Office tomorrow from 10 a.m. to noon -- we'll be holding the event rain or shine!

Melissa Ronaldson of Sun Valley High School is the "Best in Show" winner of this year's 7th Congressional District Art Competition. Melissa's work, titled "Not Afraid of the Dark", will join winners from districts across the country and hang in the US Capitol. Congratulations to Melissa and all the other talented winners in each category of art this year.
Great turn out last night at Upper Darby High School for our annual spring Job Fair with Senator Tom McGarrigle and PA State Rep. Jamie Santora.
Starting soon (despite the weather!): a free drive-thru shred event at my District Office in Springfield.
Joined PA State Rep. Alex Charlton this morning for a free shred event -- and we had quite a turnout despite the weather. Thanks to all who joined us today.
Wishing a Happy Mother's Day to my wife, Carolyn, and every other mother today.
Joined Congressman Brendan Boyle and Ed Rendell at Philadelphia International Airport this morning to talk about the need for investment in infrastructure.

Last week, I hosted one of my favorite events of the year, the Scholar Athlete Ceremony at Garnet Valley High School. The Scholar Athlete Award is given to students who exemplify the selfless dedication to school and sports that define the leaders of tomorrow. Some 100 students from more than 50 high schools across the 7th District were honored with their families at the reception featuring our keynote speaker Mike Costanzo, a former Philadelphia Phillie and the head baseball coach at Archbishop Carrol High School in Radnor. I congratulate the award winners, their parents and families and I wish all of them the best for the future.
At a meeting of the Bipartisan Heroin Task Force this afternoon to discuss the growing challenge of synthetic opioids.
Had the opportunity to chat with students from Villanova University on Capitol Hill this morning to talk about some of the challenges and opportunities before Congress today.

Bob Mueller is a man of integrity and I have every confidence he will pursue this investigation and follow the facts, wherever they lead him. His appointment as Special Counsel should give the American people confidence that the investigation into Russia’s activities surrounding the 2016 election will be conducted thoroughly and free of political influence. I applaud Deputy Attorney General Rosenstein’s decision.

Paid tribute to the men and women of law enforcement on the House floor today, particularly those wounded in the line like Folcroft's Officer Christopher Dorman, who was bravely back at work just weeks after being shot in the line of duty, and those from Pennsylvania who lost their lives last year:   Pennsylvania State Trooper Eugene Weaver  Canonsburg Patrolman Scott Bashioum  Pennsylvania Corrections Officer David Weaver  Luzerne County Corrections Officer Kristopher Moules
Important community forum next week in Springfield, Delaware County on the opioid epidemic.
Horrifying news out of Manchester last night. My thoughts and prayers are with the victims, their families and first responders on the scene.

On the House floor today: the #PRIVATEAct, which will help protect our servicemen and women from the nonconsensual sharing of intimate photos. It increases protections for victims and strengthens the Uniform Code of Military Justice to help commanders crack down on inappropriate sharing of such photos.
NA
A nice story this Memorial Day weekend.

Some good news: $5.8 million in federal dollars on the way to help Southeastern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority (SEPTA) implement a critical safety technology along its expansion of the Media/Elwyn line.

Yesterday, I visited Accolade in Plymouth Meeting, Montgomery County to see the great work they are doing to create a better healthcare experience. Accolade's Health Assistants provide on-demand healthcare concierge for employees and consumers, which leads to better healthcare decisions and lower healthcare costs.
Talking about the need for pro-growth tax reform as part of the 2017 Villanova University School of Law's Tax Policy Symposium this morning.

Along with Donald Norcross and Congresswoman Lisa Blunt Rochester, I'm urging Governors Wolf, Carney and Christie to expedite sharing of Prescription Drug Monitoring Program (PDMP) information, a crucial tool in the fight against opioid abuse.

If America is going to be a global leader, it needs to have a seat at the table when issues and agreements with global implications are discussed.   The Paris Agreement isn’t perfect. But by abandoning it, America is relinquishing that seat at the table. It calls into question our commitment to protecting and preserving the environment. And it forfeits our ability to drive countries like China and India to reduce their carbon footprint and compete on a level playing field. Ultimately, this disappointing decision diminishes America’s leadership role on the world stage.

Honored to be on hand this week for the SCORE Mentors Chester & Delaware County 2017 Small Business Achievement Award luncheon. I'm pictured here with Seta Babayan-MacCrory, the founder of Substitoothfairy, Dental Staffing Service and Colleen McCloskey, founder of Elite Pureed Meals.
Beautiful weather and great turnout for today's annual Plymouth Township Day.
Had the opportunity on Friday to sit down with a group of mushroom farmers in Avondale, Chester County to learn of some of the challenges and opportunities for our region's mushroom industry.

Had the opportunity last week to visit Chatham Financial, a global financial services and advisory firm headquartered in Kennett Square, to meet some of their employees and learn more about the work they do for their clients around the world.
Honoring the memory and service of President Ronald Reagan, who passed away 13 years ago today.

With my friend Congressman Bill Shuster at the White House today as the President launched an effort to overhaul our air traffic control system. Reforming our antiquated air traffic control infrastructure will mean fewer delays and missed flights and safer air travel for millions of Americans, particularly in the busy airspace above our region.
Remembering the many brave Americans and their allies who faced down harrowing danger in Normandy 73 years ago today.

This upgrade is sorely needed and long overdue. It will help veterans’ health records follow them after they retire from the service, which will ease their transition into civilian life and reduce interruptions to care. It will improve the sharing of information between the VA’s Health and Benefits Administrations, and I’m hopeful that it will reduce the time needed to attach medical records to benefits claims. It will also help the VA protect against cyber attacks on its healthcare infrastructure.  This is an encouraging step. I applaud Secretary Shulkin and the Trump Administration and I look forward to continuing to work to improve the VA,.

On the House Floor today: a resolution condemning the violence against protesters outside the Turkish Embassy in Washington last month and calling for the perpetrators to be brought to justice. It's expected to pass with broad bipartisan support.

Chris Wray is a terrific choice by the President to lead the FBI at this critical moment in time. He will bring credibility, credentials and great character to the role and will instantly earn the respect of the Bureau’s agents and other law enforcement across the nation.”  In the wake of the Enron scandal, I was honored to serve on the President’s Corporate Fraud Task Force, on which Chris was a driving force. His judgment is sound, his command of complex topics complete and his demeanor even-heeled. He was previously confirmed by unanimous consent for a top position in the Justice Department and he should be as well-received by the Senate again. I commend the President for his patient search and his wise selection.
Spoke with NBC10 Philadelphia's Lauren Mayk on Capitol Hill this morning about the President's nomination of Christopher Wray to lead the FBI.

On hand this morning at Ridley Middle School to honor Dr. Arthur Smith for his 48 years of service to the Ridley School District. Over the course of Dr. Smith's career, he has taught over 9,000 students at the Middle School.  Dr. Smith, thank you for your service, dedication, and love of teaching. Congratulations on your retirement.
Enjoyed stopping by Senator Tom McGarrigle's Kids Day this afternoon. The event featured moon bounces, craft activities, and resources for parents.
Had a great time today at Prospect Park's first Community Day. It's a beautiful day to celebrate community pride.
Congratulations to the Springfield High School Cougars, the 2017 PIAA Boys Lacrosse State Champions!
With my colleagues from both sides of the aisle this morning to talk about the need to modernize our infrastructure at the Southeastern Pennsylvania Labor-Management Infrastructure Summit.

With my colleague Donald Norcross this morning to talk about the importance of interstate information sharing among prescription drug monitoring programs, critical tools in the fight against opioid abuse.
6abc Action News was on hand yesterday as I joined Donald Norcross to discuss the importance of information sharing among Prescription Drug Monitoring Programs.
Happy to have Lawrence Feinberg of the Haverford School District's School Board in to my Washington office a few minutes ago to talk federal education policy.

Some good news: Pennsylvania has just been awarded $12 million from the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services through its Children's Mental Health Initiative, which will help young people access needed mental health care after experiencing serious emotional disturbances.

With Theodore Roosevelt IV, great grandson of President Teddy Roosevelt, as well as my Senior Legislative Assistant Jim Gray, to talk about conservation efforts and the importance of the Land and Water Conservation Fund.

I was not at this morning's Congressional baseball practice and all of our staff members are accounted for. My thoughts and prayers are with my colleagues, the staffers and the U.S. Capitol Police officers involved in this morning's shooting.

Starting soon: a hearing of the bipartisan Task Force to End Sexual Violence, featuring testimony from Law & Order: Special Victims Unit's Mariska Hargitay on how we can reduce the rape kit backlog. Watch live starting at 9:00 a.m. via CSPAN-2 or right here on Facebook.
Watch now: Law & Order: Special Victims Unit's Mariska Hargitay is appearing before the bipartisan Task Force to End Sexual Assault on Capitol Hill this morning.
Mariska Hargitay appeared yesterday before the bipartisan Task Force to End Sexual Violence. The topic: ending the rape kit backlog.
Wishing my fellow fathers a Happy Fathers Day today.
Had the opportunity to visit Proto-Cast LLC, a manufacturer in Berks County, to talk about some of the challenges facing our region's small and mid-size manufacturing firms.
From last week: expressing my appreciation to wounded United States Capitol Police Special Agent David Bailey for his heroism during the events of last Wednesday morning.

Joined the Berks Visiting Nurse Association yesterday to visit Dorothy, a 94 year old Berks County resident receiving hospice care. High-quality in-home care is vital to the quality of life of so many Pennsylvania seniors.

Yesterday, Anna Ferraro, a Perkiomen Valley High School student, spent the day shadowing my District Office for a school career project. Anna had a first-hand opportunity to learn from my staff how constituent services plays an important role in my job as a Member of Congress.

June is Alzheimer’s & Brain Awareness Month and today is #TheLongestDay, a special day of action for the Alzheimer’s community. I’m wearing purple in support of the more than five million Americans living with Alzheimer’s. #EndALZ

I'm working on bipartisan legislation to reduce on-campus hazing by requiring colleges and universities to disclose harmful hazing incidents as part of their annual crime reports. More from the Philadelphia Inquirer here:

Pleased to join my colleagues Congresswoman Katherine Clark and Congresswoman Susan W. Brooks to introduce legislation that cracks down on predatory behavior online.

This week, 154 years ago: the Battle of Gettysburg, just a hundred or so miles west of our area. Three of the Union's top commanders at Gettysburg hailed from Pennsylvania. Pictured are Major Generals John Reynolds of Lancaster, killed in the opening stages of the battle, Winfield Scott Hancock of Montgomery County, and George G. Meade of Philadelphia, overall commander of Union forces at Gettysburg.
Wishing you and your family a happy and safe Fourth of July.
Great to see so many friends in Marple and Springfield for today's July Fourth festivities.

Congratulations to Eric Gershman, a teacher from the Springfield Township School District in Montgomery County, who was selected from a pool of more than 300 teachers to participate in The Library of Congress Teaching with Primary Sources Summer Teacher Institute. Over the course of the weeklong program, the participants will work with library specialists to learn how to better utilize primary sources and have the opportunity to explore millions of collections and artifacts stored on the Library’s website. Educators -- and others -- can learn about some of the resources the Library provides by visiting its website below.

Montgomery County has declared a Code Red Hot Weather Health Warning for Montgomery County from 11 a.m. to 8 p.m. on Thursday, July 13, 2017. It will be a particularly hot day out there across our region, so during this time, please make sure to check on those who may be at risk, including the elderly, people with disabilities, children, and pets.

Had the honor of being joined on Capitol Hill this morning by Representative Marcia L. Fudge, former Senator Richard Lugar of The Lugar Center, Penn State Provost Dr. Nick Jones, the DeVercelly family, whose son Gary Jr. died in a hazing incident in 2007, and others to urge passage of bipartisan anti-campus hazing legislation.
Very moving to have Gary and Julie Devercelly with me on Capitol Hill this morning to talk about anti-hazing legislation I've proposed with Representative Marcia L. Fudge.
Some good news for Horsham and the surrounding communities affected by the detection of PFOS/PFOA compounds in their drinking water.
A good editorial in today's LNP + LancasterOnline.com about legislation I've introduced that takes aim at dangerous on-campus hazing.

Urging U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development Secretary Ben Carson to prohibit tax-delinquent landlords from receiving federal Housing Choice Voucher Program funds. Federal tax dollars should not support landlords who aren't paying their fair share of property taxes to local communities and school districts.
Joined the National Council of Youth Sports (NCYS) on Capitol Hill this morning to talk about the important benefits of competitive sports for kids.
Two years later, the Iran nuclear deal is still a bad deal for the United States. My op-ed in today's Washington Times Opinion explains why.
My friend and former colleague in the House of Representatives, Senator Jeff Flake, said it best: a tough diagnosis for Senator McCain has met an even tougher man.

Overwhelming bipartisan support a few moments ago for a House-passed bill approving sanctions on Russia, North Korea & Iran. These sanctions put hostile regimes in Moscow, Tehran and Pyongyang on notice. For eight years under President Obama, accountability took a back seat to accommodation when it came to our adversaries on the world stage. Each of these regimes continues to pursue campaigns of aggression and belligerence, but today’s bipartisan vote shows they will not go unpunished.  These sanctions will hit these regimes where it will hurt, and they’ll limit our enemies’ access to the hard cash necessary to finance aggression, human rights abuses and support for terror. I’m pleased to see the legislation approved by the House and I hope the Senate acts to send it to the President’s desk for his signature promptly.

An estimated 58,000 American children are ordered by our courts into the custody of abusive parents, in many cases over the objections of another parent. As a result, too many kids face trauma, injury or even death that could have been prevented by improved custody and visitation adjudications. This resolution makes it clear that the top priority in any such adjudication is the safety of the child involved and it will encourage states to develop standards that will help keep our courts from inadvertently delivering children into the hands of abusive parents.
Both my Washington, D.C. and Springfield District Offices are currently seeking fall interns. Interested applicants can contact (202) 225-2011 or (610) 690-7323 for more information.

"More than 580 children were murdered by a parent in the midst of a divorce, custody or support case in the U.S. in the past decade, according to the Center for Judicial Excellence, a California-based national advocacy group for abuse survivors in the family court system.  'Many of these were preventable murders, with parents repeatedly warning family courts about life-threatening danger to their children, but they were ignored,' said Kathleen Russell, the center's executive director.  That is why last week, U.S. Rep. Pat Meehan, a Delaware County Republican representing part of Berks County, and U.S. Rep. Carolyn B. Maloney, a Democrat from New York, introduced a resolution calling for hearings on family courts' practices. The resolution also advises state courts to improve adjudications of custody issues when family violence is alleged."
Sad news. Jan was a passionate advocate and a strong voice for what she believed in. My condolences to her family.

The Urban Outfitters e-commerce fulfillment facility in Gap, Lancaster County supports hundreds of jobs. I had the opportunity to visit and tour the facility this afternoon.

This morning, I was honored to present the Congressional Award Bronze Medal and Silver Medals to three students from the 7th Congressional District. The Congressional Award is a public private partnership created by Congress to promote and recognize achievement, initiative, and service in America’s youth. Anish, Allison, and Julia went above and beyond to achieve challenging goals in four areas: voluntary public service, personal development, physical fitness and expedition/exploration. Congratulations to these students!

Had the opportunity to visit the International Association of Heat and Frost Insulators and Allied Workers today to talk about legislation I've co-sponsored that makes insulation replacement a tax-deductible expense.
Joined the folks from Monroe Energy over the weekend for its Family Day. Always great to see so many friends and familiar faces.

Thank you to Advanced Rx for hosting me yesterday for a tour of its facility and a discussion on the work they do as a compounding pharmacy.

Great to meet so many folks at beautiful Weaver's Orchard in Morgantown yesterday afternoon.
Wishing all a happy and safe Labor Day this weekend.

I am pleased to announce that the 7th Congressional District will participate in the Congressional Veteran Commendation (CVC). The CVC is a nominations-based program designed to recognize the wartime sacrifices and peacetime community involvement of residents of the 7th District of Pennsylvania.    The public is invited to submit nomination applications for veterans that they believe have made significant community contributions to the 7th District. Honorees will be chosen by a board of veterans who represent each county throughout the district. The program intends to emphasize what veterans did when they returned home and how they made a difference in their community.  The nomination application is now open and can be found at here: https://meehan.house.gov/sites/meehan.house.gov/files/CVC%20Nomination%20Form.docx.   All applications are due by September 11, 2017.

Apprenticeships are invaluable skills training programs and a terrific pathway to a good-paying middle-class career. Allowing individuals to use "529" college savings plans for apprenticeship expenses -- like you already can today with college textbooks -- will make them more affordable for hardworking Americans.
The House this afternoon approved a $7.85 billion aid package for #Harvey victims.

Our tax code is a mess. Its rates are too high, and too many loopholes enable the elites to avoid them. It’s holding us back in the modern economy. Too much of a middle class family’s paycheck is going to Washington. A top-to-bottom rewrite is long overdue.
One of the very special moments on the House floor. Welcoming back our friend Steve Scalise.  Tears in many eyes, and many answered prayers.
With Speaker Paul Ryan today at Penn Machine in Aston talking tax reform and how it can create manufacturing jobs right here in Pennsylvania.

Each year I have the privilege of nominating a limited number of students to four of the five U.S. service academies: U.S. Military Academy, U.S. Naval Academy, U.S. Air Force Academy, and the U.S. Merchant Marine Academy.   The deadline to apply for a nomination through my office is October 13, 2017. The application can be found on my website: www.meehan.house.gov. I always enjoy the chance to see so many friends at the Delaware County Run for Heroes each year. Thanks to all who came out this morning.

Had the chance yesterday to present the Congressional Award to two young men from Delaware County, Grant Stephano and John Mohler. It was a particularly special occasion for John’s father, who is waging a heroic fight against ALS.

Six years ago, I stood across the street from the then-Conoco refinery in Trainer and vowed to fight to save the jobs at risk from the facility’s planned closure. Today I joined employees and lawmakers from both parties braving the rain at the refinery this morning to fight for hundreds of jobs again at risk, this time threatened by the Renewable Fuel Standard. The RFS is a well-intentioned but broken Washington regulation that is driving up costs for refiners and threatens to kill middle class jobs in our community.

Outstanding speakers today at our annual Youth Leadership Summit at Marple-Newtown High School -- Patrice Banks, founder of Girls Auto Clinic, Rafael Ilishayev, the co-founder of GoPuff, and Bryan Anderson, an Iraq War vet and triple amputee, author and actor.

I am pleased to announce that the 7th Congressional District will be participating in the third Congressional App Challenge (CAC).   The CAC is an app competition for students in high school and below. Students entering the competition must submit a video of their app and what they learned through this competition process by November 1, 2017.   To enter the competition or to learn more please visit the CAC website: http://www.congressionalappchallenge.us/.
Joined PA State Rep. Todd Stephens on Saturday to celebrate Horsham Township's Tricentennial Anniversary.

Had the opportunity to visit the remarkable YSC Academy in Wayne, which combines a world-class soccer training program with a rigorous high school academic curriculum. It was inspiring to meet so many driven and talented young people.

Enjoyed being a part of Holy Child Academy’s STEAM Lab Dedication earlier today. The Lab teaches and reinforces 21st century skills needed for success in our economy and society. I even got a surprise myself today: a birthday cake from students and the mascot.

I had the opportunity to be on hand on Saturday as the Broomall Fire Company broke ground on its new firehouse. It will be a terrific new home to the first responders who put their lives on the line for our safety every day.
Praying for all those affected by today's events in Lower Manhattan.

November is National Diabetes Month, a time to bring attention to this chronic disease that affects more than 30 million Americans. The National Diabetes Education Program aims to improve treatment and outcomes for people with diabetes, promote early diagnosis, and prevent or delay the onset of type 2 diabetes. To learn more about the National Diabetes Education Program, please visit the National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Disease’s website.

Our tax code is broken. Too much comes out of the pockets of middle class families. It’s sending good-paying American jobs overseas. It’s just not getting the job done for hardworking taxpayers. Today, my colleagues on the House Ways and Means Committee and I released legislation that would revamp our tax code and put it to work for the middle class. It makes filing your taxes simpler and will spur job growth that will put Pennsylvanians back to work. Most importantly, it brings real tax relief to those who need it most: hardworking Pennsylvania taxpayers.   Learn more here.

Via the Tax Foundation: Who gets a tax cut under the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act?  The Bottom Line: "Our results indicate a reduction in tax liability for every scenario we modeled, with some of the largest cuts accruing to moderate-income families with children and fixed-income retirees."

Some good news: the House just passed the Championing Healthy Kids Act. It extends funding for the Children's Health Insurance Program, which provides health care coverage for more than 175,000 Pennsylvania kids.

"...In their haste to condemn the GOP tax plan, Democrats have spread far and wide the false claim that families making less than $86,100 on average will face a hefty tax hike. Actually, it’s the opposite. Most families in that income range would get a tax cut."

On hand this morning at Children's Hospital of Philadelphia to the celebrate the 25th anniversary of the Children’s Health Insurance Program (CHIP) and to discuss the importance of reauthorizing it for Pennsylvania families.

My District Office in Springfield, Delaware County is seeking interns for the Spring 2018 semester. This is a great opportunity for students to learn about public service and how a congressional office operates. If you are interested in learning more, please call my office at 610-690-7323.

Over the last few months, I've met with constituents who have voiced concern about the ongoing construction of the Mariner East II Pipeline. Pipeline construction can be an important part of our growing energy economy in southeastern Pennsylvania, but the highest priority must be the safety of the workers and communities involved. Earlier this week I wrote Gov. Tom Wolf to urge him to address the concerns of affected residents.
While pipelines can be an important part of the state’s energy economy, public safety must be the top priority in any such project.

This morning I attended a ribbon cutting ceremony for the Chester County Department of Veterans Affairs’ new office. The office moved to the first floor in order to accommodate more veterans and provide better accessibility and service. I’m proud of the great work that the Department does for our service men and women and their families.

Courtesy of the Tax Foundation, here's what the tax cut bill on the House floor today will mean for several different sample taxpayers.  "Our results indicate a reduction in tax liability for every scenario we estimated, with some of the largest changes in after-tax income accruing to moderate-income families with children."

Some good news for middle-class Pennslyvania families. I'm pleased to see the final bill preserved some important deductions like mortgage interest, charitable contributions, state and local property or income taxes and medical expenses. The bill lowers rates across the board and will put more money back into the pockets of hardworking taxpayers.

Took to the House Floor today to call for a long-term extension of the Children's Health Insurance Program. The House passed a five year extension last month but the Senate has not taken action. Just a few moments ago passed a short-term extension of CHIP through March that will hopefully be adopted by the Senate. A short-term extension is good, but we need to do better.
From my family to yours, Merry Christmas!
